_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities.

 

1.1 O'Neill Vintners & Distillers, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name               | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

P1 - Main Processing         Anhydrous Ammonia                27,000

P2 - 900 Farm                Anhydrous Ammonia                15,000

P4 - Sulfur Dioxide          Sulfur Dioxide                    8,000

P5 - Remote 900              Anhydrous Ammonia                12,500



Note: Process 3 (Trailer Package) was decommissioned in 2016 with the installation of Process 5. Process 5 was designed by Axiom Engineers and installed by Cold Storage Technologies.



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enab

les our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers operates a processing facility for wine and other alcoholic beverages in Parlier, CA. The facility has three ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:



Process 1 - Main Processing

(9) Shell & Tube Heat Exchangers

(3) Plate Heat Exchangers



Process 2 - 900 Tank Farm

(2) Shell & Tube Heat Exchangers



Process 5 - Remote 900

(3) Shell & Tube Heat Exchangers

(1) Plate Heat Exchanger



Note: Process 3 (Trailer Package) was decommissioned in 2016 with the installation of Process 5. Process 5 was designed by Axiom Engineers and installed by Cold Storage Technologies.



The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly adjacent to each machinery room/area. A partial list of system components includes:



Machinery Room (Main Processing)

(2) Reciprocating compressors

(4) Screw compressors

(6) Oil separators

(4) Shell and tube oil coolers

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Main suction accumulator

(1) Thermosyphon vessel



Chiller Room

(1) Surge drum

(2) Plate heat exchangers

(1) Oil pot

(5) Accumulators

(5) Shell & tube heat exchangers



Condenser Area

(3

) Evaporative condensers

(4) Accumulators

(4) Shell & tube heat exchangers



Diffusion Tank Area

(1) Diffusion tank

(1) Surge drum

(1) Plate heat exchanger

(1) Oil pot



Outdoor Machinery Area (900 Tank Farm)

(3) Screw compressors

(3) Oil separators

(2) Evaporative condensers

(2) Shell & tube heat exchangers

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Main suction accumulator



Diffusion Tank Area

(1) Diffusion tank



Chiller System Area (Remote 900)

(2) Screw compressors

(1) Reciprocating compressor

(3) Oil separators

(1) Evaporative condenser

(1) Thermosyphon vessel

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Suction accumulator

(1) Plate Heat Exchanger

(3) Shell & tube heat exchangers

(2) Oil pots

(1) Diffusion tank



The flooded system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each heat exchanger, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator mounted above the heat exchanger. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through heat exchanger. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator.  From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the thermosyphon vessel and then to the high pressure receiver.



Each system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to a diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 



There is one ammonia detector installed inside the refrigeration machinery room

and chiller room. Each sensor is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate both mechanical ventilation systems at a normal rate of 20 air changes per hour and activate an audible alarm and strobe.



Each of the ammonia refrigeration systems at O'Neill Vintners & Distillers consists of vessels, valves, equipment which are interconnected by piping to form a closed-loop system. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located in respect to each other. Therefore, O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has three ammonia processes.



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has one sulfur-dioxide process, which is listed below:



Process 4: Sulfur-Dioxide - Four 1-ton containers



Sulfur-dioxide is injected during the crush and periodically thereafter into the storage tanks acting as a preservative for the wine.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the O'Neill Vintners & Distillers facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 54,500 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of a

n ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.3.3 Sulfur-Dioxide



The sulfur-dioxide process at the O'Neill Vintners & Distillers facility is an integral part of overall business and lasts for approximately five months out of the year. The sulfur-dioxide process contains multiple cylinders with a maximum inventory of 8,000 lbs. It is extremely important that these areas and associated injection processes are maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. O'Neill Vintners & Distillers is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of exposure to sulfur-dioxide.



Our personnel also monitor the sulfur-dioxide fumigation process and keep an active log of all associated procedures and transactions. In addition, the process is checked frequently during the season by the outside contractor that supplies the SO2 cylinders. The contractor also assists in performing the annual mechanical integrity review of our process equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous

Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, O'Neill Vintners & Distillers continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved O'Neill Vintners & Distillers' ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that O'Neill Vintners & Distillers' management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, O'Neill Vintners & Distillers now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for O'Neill Vintners & Distillers employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program O'Neill Vintners & Distillers will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public
